conversation.content: My account balance shows two different amounts. I need clarification on what's actually available to spend today.
I understand your concern. Let me access your account and explain the difference between your available balance and posted balance. May I have your account number?
It's 445-890-2341. There's a three hundred dollar difference between the two balances shown.
Thank you. I can see your posted balance is $2,847.50 and your available balance is $2,547.50, which reflects a $300 pending transaction from Hartley Electronics.
What exactly does pending mean? The purchase was three days ago but it's still not finalized.
Certainly.
So when will that transaction actually post to my account?
Pending transactions are temporary holds that merchants place on your funds. Most retail transactions like your TRX-884290 from Hartley Electronics typically post within 2-5 business days.
Does the pending amount count against my daily spending limit or overdraft protection?
Yes, pending transactions immediately reduce your available balance to prevent overspending. Your daily limit of $5,000 factors in both posted and pending amounts for real-time accuracy.
I see another pending charge for seventy-five dollars that I don't recognize.
I can see that pending authorization PA-7829-441 for $75.00 from Digital Streaming Services. This appears to be an annual subscription renewal that initiated yesterday at 3:47 PM.
Can pending transactions be cancelled or do I have to wait for them to post first?
Of course.
What happens if a pending transaction never posts? I had one disappear last month.

Pending authorizations automatically expire after their hold period, typically 3-7 business days depending on the merchant category. When authorization AU-9982-KL expired last month, those funds became immediately available again.
Should I track my spending based on the posted or available balance?
Always use your available balance for spending decisions. This reflects your true purchasing power after accounting for all pending transactions, ensuring you won't overdraft your account.
That makes sense. Can you send me documentation about how these transactions process?

Absolutely. I'll email our transaction processing guide to your registered address within the next hour. Is there anything else regarding your account reference ACC-445890-2341 that I can clarify today?

scenario: confused about the difference between pending and posted transactions
